sections.title: Brokerage Accounts
sections.content: Online brokerages offer the widest investment menu—stocks, bonds, ETFs, mutual funds, and options. Look for zero-commission trades, robust research, and cash sweep programs. Consider whether you need advanced tools or if a clean interface suffices.

sections.title: Robo-Advisors and Employer Plans
sections.content: Robo-advisors automate portfolio construction, automatically rebalancing based on your risk profile for a modest fee. Employer-sponsored plans like 401(k)s offer tax benefits and often matching contributions—take advantage before opening taxable accounts.

points.title: Account Types
points.description: Ensure the platform supports IRAs, HSAs, custodial accounts, or taxable brokerage accounts as needed.

points.title: Costs
points.description: Review trading commissions, advisory fees, fund expense ratios, and transfer fees.

points.title: Tools and Support
points.description: Assess mobile apps, goal-planning tools, live chat, and phone support availability.

sections.title: Watch Hidden Fees
sections.content: A 0.25% annual advisory fee on a $25,000 account equals $62.50 per year—small at first but significant as balances grow.

sections.title: Platform Selection Sprint
steps: List must-have features (e.g., fractional shares, automatic deposits, socially conscious funds).
Collect data from at least two providers on fees, account types, and minimums.
Open a trial or demo account to test usability and research tools.
Decide which platform you will use for each goal (retirement, taxable investing, education savings).

sections.title: Consolidate When Possible
sections.content: Keeping most accounts under one provider simplifies tracking and reduces the chance of missing required minimum distributions or tax forms.
